This involves knowingly trafficking in counterfeit labels or illicit labels affixed to various types of works or counterfeit documentation or packaging. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" and the "Anti-counterfeiting Amendments Act of 2004" prohibit trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. This involves trafficking in counterfeit labels or illicit labels affixed to various types of works, including literary, pictorial, graphic, or sculptural works, visual art, documentation, or packaging. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of the term "illicit label" in relation to copyright protection. It defines an illicit label as a genuine certificate or labeling component used by the copyright owner for verification purposes. The curr_chunk defines the term "illicit label" as a genuine certificate used by the copyright owner to verify the authenticity of various works without authorization. The curr_chunk discusses the distribution of counterfeit works without authorization from the copyright owner, including falsifying genuine certificates to indicate a higher number of licensed users or copies. The curr_chunk defines 'documentation or packaging' as physical documentation or packaging for a phonorecord or copy. The curr_chunk clarifies the terms 'documentation or packaging' and 'counterfeit documentation or packaging' in the context of verifying noninfringement. The curr_chunk defines 'counterfeit documentation or packaging' as appearing genuine but not authentic, and specifies the types of items it can be affixed to. The curr_chunk expands on the definition of 'counterfeit documentation or packaging' by listing various types of copyrighted works it can be attached to, such as musical works, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, visual art, and documentation. It also includes amendments to subsection (d) regarding counterfeit and illicit labels. The curr_chunk further amends subsection (d) of Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code by adding provisions related to counterfeit and illicit labels, as well as equipment used in their production. Additionally, it introduces civil remedies for copyright owners who suffer injury. The curr_chunk introduces civil remedies for copyright owners affected by violations of subsection (a) of Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. This allows copyright owners to bring a civil action in a US district court and seek injunctions to prevent further violations. The court can grant injunctions to prevent violations of subsection (a), order the impounding of relevant articles, and award attorney fees and costs to the injured party. The court may award attorney fees, costs, actual damages, additional profits, or statutory damages to the injured party for a violation of subsection (a). The injured party is entitled to recover actual damages and profits from a violation of subsection (a). Actual damages are calculated by multiplying the value of the phonorecords, copies, or works. The court calculates actual damages by multiplying the value of counterfeit items by the number of those items. The value of counterfeit items is determined by multiplying the value of each item by the number of items. The value of copyrighted works is based on the retail value of authorized copies, such as sound recordings, musical works, computer programs, motion pictures, audiovisual works, and literary works. The retail value of authorized copies of copyrighted works is used to determine statutory damages for infringement. The injured party may choose to receive statutory damages instead of actual damages and profits, ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 per violation. The court has the discretion to triple the damages for subsequent violations. The court may award damages exceeding $25,000 for violations of subsection (a), with the possibility of tripling the amount for subsequent violations within 3 years. A civil action must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the violation. The civil action for violations of subsection (a) must be initiated within 3 years of discovery. The fair use of certain components described in section 2318(b) of Title 18, United States Code, is protected. TITLE II--FRAUDULENT ONLINE IDENTITY SANCTIONS

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as the "Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act".

SEC. 202. AMENDMENT TO TRADEMARK ACT OF 1946. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a new subsection that establishes a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided in cases of trademark infringement. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to establish a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided in cases of trademark infringement. This applies to individuals who knowingly provide false contact information to domain name authorities when registering, maintaining, or renewing a domain name used in connection with the violation. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. The amendment to Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code includes a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. This provision does not limit what may be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined in section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946. The 'Trademark Act of 1946' provides for the registration and protection of trademarks used in commerce, in accordance with international conventions. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Sentencing Enhancement: If a defendant convicted of a felony offense knowingly falsely registered a domain name and used it in the course of the offense, the maximum imprisonment for that offense will be doubled or increased by 7 years, whichever is less. "Falsely registers" means registering in a way that prevents identification or contact with the person who registers. The term "falsely registers" means registering in a manner that prevents effective identification or contact with the person who registers. The term "domain name" is defined in section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for defendants convicted of online felony offenses facilitated by a domain name registered with false information. The Sentencing Commission will amend guidelines to enhance sentences for felony offenses involving false contact information provided to domain name registrars. The Sentencing Commission will provide sentencing enhancements for felony offenses involving knowingly providing false contact information to domain name registrars, registries, or registration authorities for a domain name used in connection with the violation. The term "domain name" is defined as per section 45 of the Act related to trademark registration and protection. The term "domain name" is defined in section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 205 of the text states that the title does not affect free speech or press rights related to domain name registration. It also does not limit court discretion in determining damages, relief, or imprisonment terms for intellectual property rights infringement. TITLE III--COURTS

SEC. 301. ADDITIONAL PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE DISTRICT OF COLORADO.

Section 85 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include "Colorado Springs," after "Boulder,".

SEC. 302. PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK.
